title: Contributing
text: repository designed match internal style guidelines Birmingham Solihull ICS reports projects, recommendations improvements please feel free create issue. BSOL ICB team members, note directly commit main branch. Please create changes separate branch master. ready, create pull request merge changes back master. create pull request, ensure : created unit tests (using testthat) github actions builds successfully new branch changes making partial finished piece work changes signed managers discussed team

title: Colours
text: view possible colours available, can use following function: bsol_theme_cols function returns named vectored hex-encoded RGB values colours. interested specific colours, can specify arguments function, like : , can use one available palettes: documentation bsol_theme_cols lists palettes available use. colours shown .
code: bsol_theme_cols() #>       green  light_blue      orange   deep_navy      purple    nhs_blue  #>   "#8cedab"   "#4fbff0"   "#fc8700"   "#031d44"   "#b88ce3"   "#005EB8"  #> light_slate    charcoal       white  #>   "#b2b7b9"   "#2c2825"   "#ffffff" bsol_theme_cols("orange", "light_slate", "nhs_blue") #>      orange light_slate    nhs_blue  #>   "#fc8700"   "#b2b7b9"   "#005EB8" bsol_theme_cols(palette = "main") #>      green light_blue     orange  deep_navy     purple  #>  "#8cedab"  "#4fbff0"  "#fc8700"  "#031d44"  "#b88ce3"

title: Colours
text: want use Strategy Unit’s colours plots, can use scale_colour_bsol scale_fill_bsol functions. example, wish use main palette:  can also change specify different palette, reverse order like :  functions default discrete data. continuous need set discrete argument FALSE.
code: ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_colour_bsol() ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_colour_bsol(palette = "ics_purple", reverse = TRUE) ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_bsol(discrete = FALSE, palette = "ics_orange", reverse = TRUE)

what: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
text: Format converting R Markdown BSOL branded MS Word document.

title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
code: bsol_document(   toc = FALSE,   toc_depth = 1,   fig_caption = TRUE,   df_print = "kable",   highlight = "default",   keep_md = FALSE,   md_extensions = NULL,   pandoc_args = NULL )

title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
text: toc TRUE include table contents output toc_depth Depth headers include table contents fig_caption TRUE render figures captions df_print Method used printing data frames. Valid values include "default", "kable", "tibble", "paged". "default" method uses corresponding S3 method print, typically print.data.frame. "kable" method uses knitr::kable function. "tibble" method uses tibble package print summary data frame. "paged" method creates paginated HTML table (note method valid formats produce HTML). addition named methods can also pass arbitrary function used printing data frames. can disable df_print behavior entirely setting option rmarkdown.df_print FALSE. See Data frame printing section bookdown book examples. highlight Syntax highlighting style passed Pandoc. Supported built-styles include "default", "tango", "pygments", "kate",  "monochrome", "espresso", "zenburn", "haddock", "breezedark". Two custom styles also included, "arrow", accessible color scheme,   "rstudio", mimics default IDE theme. Alternatively, supply   path .theme file use   custom Pandoc   style. Note custom theme requires Pandoc 2.0+. Pass NULL prevent syntax highlighting. keep_md Keep markdown file generated knitting. md_extensions Markdown extensions added removed default definition R Markdown. See rmarkdown_format additional details. pandoc_args Additional command line options pass pandoc

title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
text: R Markdown output format pass render

title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
text: See online documentation additional details using word_document format.

title: Convert to an BSOL Word document — bsol_document
code: if (FALSE) { library(rmarkdown)  # simple invocation render("input.Rmd", bsol_document()) }

text: safest, reusable ways automatically add details Rmarkdown templates file add conserved 'environmental variables, users share. variables MY_NAME, MY_EMAIL, MY_JOBTITLE. function scans .Renviron file (holds variables) detects present.  adds , opens file fill .  done , please save restart R, RStudio caches file opens.

BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
text: function returns colours used BSOL ICS theme named vector RGB values hexadecimal form.

title: BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
text: ... individual colours wish get values palette name palette select colours

title: BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
text: named vector RGB colours hexadecimal form

title: BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
text: arguments passed function, colours returned. specific colours required, names colours required can passed strings function, colours returned. "palette" selected arguments passed ... one palette can selected time.

title: BSOL Theme Colours — bsol_theme_cols
code: # show all of the colours bsol_theme_cols() #>       green  light_blue      orange   deep_navy      purple    nhs_blue  #>   "#8cedab"   "#4fbff0"   "#fc8700"   "#031d44"   "#b88ce3"   "#005EB8"  #> light_slate    charcoal       white  #>   "#b2b7b9"   "#2c2825"   "#ffffff"  # or, just show some colours bsol_theme_cols("green", "orange", "deep_navy", "nhs_blue") #>     green    orange deep_navy  nhs_blue  #> "#8cedab" "#fc8700" "#031d44" "#005EB8"  # or, select a single palette bsol_theme_cols(palette = "ics_orange") #>    orange     white deep_navy  #> "#fc8700" "#ffffff" "#031d44"

what: BSOL ICS Gradient colour Scale — bsol_theme_gradient_colour_scales
title: BSOL ICS Gradient colour Scale — bsol_theme_gradient_colour_scales
text: Generates two colour gradient (low-high)

title: BSOL ICS Gradient colour Scale — bsol_theme_gradient_colour_scales
code: scale_colour_bsol(   palette = c("main", "alternative", "ics_blue", "ics_orange", "ics_green", "ics_purple",     "ics_navy"),   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   ... )  scale_color_bsol(   palette = c("main", "alternative", "ics_blue", "ics_orange", "ics_green", "ics_purple",     "ics_navy"),   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   ... )  scale_fill_bsol(   palette = c("main", "alternative", "ics_blue", "ics_orange", "ics_green", "ics_purple",     "ics_navy"),   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   ... )

title: BSOL ICS Gradient colour Scale — bsol_theme_gradient_colour_scales
text: palette name palette use discrete Optional: boolean indicate scale discrete scale. Defaults TRUE reverse Optional: boolean reverse direction scale. Defaults FALSE ... additional arguments passed ggplot functions

title: BSOL ICS Gradient colour Scale — bsol_theme_gradient_colour_scales
text: scale object used ggplot object

text: function returns palette generated colorRampPalette one BSOL palettes

BSOL ICS Theme Palettes — bsol_theme_pal
text: palette name palette use reverse Optional: boolean value reverse palette ... arguments pass colorRamp

title: BSOL ICS Theme Palettes — bsol_theme_pal
text: colorRamp function

title: BSOL ICS Theme Palettes — bsol_theme_pal
code: bsol_theme_pal("main") #> function (n)  #> { #>     x <- ramp(seq.int(0, 1, length.out = n)) #>     if (ncol(x) == 4L)  #>         rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], x[, 4L], maxColorValue = 255) #>     else rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], maxColorValue = 255) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x5638e76abed8> #> <environment: 0x5638e76aebc0> # or, specify a palette bsol_theme_pal("ics_orange") #> function (n)  #> { #>     x <- ramp(seq.int(0, 1, length.out = n)) #>     if (ncol(x) == 4L)  #>         rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], x[, 4L], maxColorValue = 255) #>     else rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], maxColorValue = 255) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x5638e76abed8> #> <environment: 0x5638e7745670> # a reverse palette bsol_theme_pal("main", TRUE) #> function (n)  #> { #>     x <- ramp(seq.int(0, 1, length.out = n)) #>     if (ncol(x) == 4L)  #>         rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], x[, 4L], maxColorValue = 255) #>     else rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], maxColorValue = 255) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x5638e76abed8> #> <environment: 0x5638e77bbc78>

title: ggplotly BSOL wrapper for passing the font size properly — ggplotly_bsol
code: library(ggplot) #> Error in library(ggplot): there is no package called ‘ggplot’ a<-ggplot(iris, aes(y=Sepal.Length, x=Sepal.Width, colour=Species))+ geom_point()+ scale_colour_bsol()+ theme_bsol() #> Error in ggplot(iris, aes(y = Sepal.Length, x = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)): could not find function "ggplot"  ggplotly_bsol(a) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'a' not found

what: Creates the BSOL Theme for ggplot — theme_bsol
title: Creates the BSOL Theme for ggplot — theme_bsol
text: Creates base theme ggplot objects.

title: Creates the BSOL Theme for ggplot — theme_bsol
Creates the BSOL Theme for ggplot — theme_bsol
text: base_family font use theme

title: Creates the BSOL Theme for ggplot — theme_bsol
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) library(BSOLTheme) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Width, Sepal.Length, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() +   theme_bsol() }
